Comment: In poker: The equivalent move would be like when the short stack bluffs and bids up the player with the most chips.  It's not a great play because you're not in a good position to be playing the hand at all and bluffing isn't a necessarily a good play from that position. You risk being forced to fold against too many hands/players. So, it's like the short stack is just donating chips to the chip leader.  It's a bad play in a bad position and the "opponent" is not likely to do anything besides play their hand as normal.

According to Alicia Garcia-Herrero, chief economist for Asia-Pacific at Natixis, China is well-positioned to get a better deal. >  > "[Trump] needs a quick deal," Garcia-Herrero told the South China Morning Post. "China does not need to offer anything big in such circumstances, because the US is so desperate for a deal. With a few billion in imports from the US, China might manage to lower the tariffs. The deal might be sweeter for China than in 2019."  >  > According to the WSJ, although China retaliated with increased tariffs on US imports to 125 percent and seemingly has not seriously engaged Trump, China remains "open to trade talks" so long as Trump keeps things civil. Comment: China already did.  China Just Turned Off U.S. Supplies Of Minerals Critical For Defense & Cleantech   https://cleantechnica.com/2025/04/05/china-just-turned-off-u-s-supplies-of-minerals-critical-for-defense-cleantech/   > What China did wasn‚Äôt a ban, at least not in name. They called it export licensing. Sounds like something a trade lawyer might actually be excited about. But make no mistake: this was a surgical strike. They didn‚Äôt need to say no. They just needed to say ‚Äúmaybe later‚Äù to the right set of paperwork. These licenses give Beijing control over not just where these materials go, but how fast they go, in what quantity, and to which politically convenient customers. >  > The U.S.? Let‚Äôs just say Washington should get comfortable waiting behind the rope line. The licenses have to be applied for and the end use including country of final destination must be clearly spelled out. Licenses for end uses in the U.S. are unlikely to be approved. What‚Äôs astonishing is how predictable this all was. China has spent decades building its dominance over these supply chains, while the U.S. was busy outsourcing, divesting, and cheerfully ignoring every report that said, ‚ÄúHey, maybe 90% dependence on a single country we keep starting trade wars with and rattling sabers at is a bad idea.‚Äù >  > Try ramping up your semiconductor fab or solar plant when your indium source just dried up. It‚Äôs a fun exercise in learning which of your suppliers used to be dependent on Beijing but never mentioned it in the quarterly call. >  > The materials China just restricted aren‚Äôt random. They‚Äôre chosen with the precision of someone who‚Äôs read U.S. product spec sheets and defense procurement orders. Start with dysprosium. If your electric motor needs to function at high temperatures‚Äîand they all do‚Äîthen mostly it is using neodymium magnets doped with dysprosium. No dysprosium, no thermal stability. No thermal stability, no functioning motor in your F-35 or your Mustang Mach-E. China controls essentially the entire supply of dysprosium, and no, there is no magical mine in Wyoming or Quebec waiting in the wings. If dysprosium doesn‚Äôt come out of China, it doesn‚Äôt come out at all. It‚Äôs the spinal cord of electrification, and right now China‚Äôs holding the vertebrae. >  > So here we are. China has responded to Trump‚Äôs tariffs by cutting off U.S. supply of some of the most essential ingredients of the modern world.

Comment: >China has little reason to rush to make a deal that ends all that, if more power can be derived from waiting it out, Chen suggested, especially since the Chinese yuan's popularity is rising amidst the US trade chaos. Instead of rushing to meet with Trump, China is apparently wooing key US ally Japan to team up to oppose Trump's tariffs, Newsweek reported Wednesday.  Japan is not happy with Trump and Republicans at the moment.  Trump Tariffs Like 'Delinquent Kid Extorting Somebody'‚ÄîJapanese Lawmaker   https://www.newsweek.com/trump-tariffs-delinquent-kid-extorting-somebody-japanese-lawmaker-2061460    >Oguma in a speech during a parliamentary committee hearing told Japanese Foreign Minister Takeshi Iwaya that the nation should resist Trump's demands, likening the U.S. approach as a "delinquent kid extorting someone," according to a Times of India translation.  >"If Japan listens to this and bends the other way in response to the impossible demands of bargaining and deals, it will set a bad example as a customary and historical precedent," Oguma said. "If you get mugged and put money in their hands, they will come back to mug us."  >Oguma called Trump's tariff formula "a mess" and questioned if it was "safe for a serious person to go there" and negotiate with the U.S.  >"Consider every option, but you should never make concessions to someone who is not straight up anyway," Oguma said, adding: "I hope that you will never give in to the American extortionists. I know this is harsh to say, but they are extortionists."  >"If you listen to what they say, it will be a really bad example," Oguma said.  >Iwaya meanwhile has called for a diplomatic approach to the still-developing U.S. trade policy, comparing the regular changes to "a daily menu." He previously called the tariffs "regrettable," according to Japanese outlet Kyodo News.  Japan Minister Speech | Japanese Leaders Attack Trump's Tariffs: 'US Tariffs Change Like Daily Menu'   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DvDCtYgv9wI

Comment: Slow burn but here is what Australia did:  \- Don't bother with reciprocal tariffs as that mostly hurts Australian consumers.    \- Provide zero interest loans to any exporters or importers who want to move their chains away from the U.S. to other markets   \- Put American companies last when it comes to Australian government contracts, including the big consulting firms and construction firms.   \- Encourage Australians to boycott American products, including streaming services, etc.   This is not going to hit Trump in any way he will be able to discern, but what it really does is insulate Australia further from the chaos of the United States.   The crazy thing is that Australia has a MUCH bigger trading relationship with China. Australia needs China to win the trade war, not the U.S.
